Award.AwardTitle: Kin Structure, Kin Recognition, and Cooperation in a Model System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kinship is a crucial element in many kinds of cooperation. In order for individuals to cooperate with their kin they must identify their relatives somehow. This can happen through the structure of the environment, or through active recognition processes. Recognition and cooperation can benefit many kinds of organisms. Some of these organisms include microbes where cooperation can actually harm the animal hosts, so understanding kin recognition and cooperation in microbes can have important implications for human welfare.

The investigators will study kin structure and recognition in a social amoeba that has a solitary stage where it eats bacteria and a social stage where it aggregates into a multi-cellular collective that moves and produces spores. They have found that this amoeba can distinguish between related and unrelated individuals and these amoebae use this ability to avoid unrelated amoebae and to protect certain kinds of bacteria. The investigators will test different mechanisms for recognizing relatives in this system. They will document the growth patterns of the amoebae as they prey upon bacteria. They will examine genes for recognition and they will consider the role of dispersal distance in recognition. Furthermore the investigators will explore the mechanisms through which these amoebae exploit the toxicity of bacteria. Taken together, this research has great potential to promote our understanding of the interactions between microbes; which in turn will contribute to our understanding of how microbes directly affect humans and the environment in which we live. The project will contribute to the scientific training of undergraduate and graduate students and will reach out to the public via websites, Wikipedia entries, and events for K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The more researchers studied competition among organisms, the more they came to realize that cooperation is equally important in the organization of life. This may make intuitive sense to humans who have studied the history of warfare, or witnessed team sports, where cooperation within sides determines victory between sides. If this view is important in nature, it means that organisms are not loners, but work in groups. These groups could be families, or aggregations. They could be made up of similar or different individuals. They could have diverse different kinds of internal structure.

Of all these kinds, groups of relatives are of particular interest, because the same gene for cooperation can be in both the actor and the recipient of cooperation. It is this kind of cooperation, in particular how relatives end up in the same place and are favored, that the research covered by this proposal investigated. The other kind of cooperation studied here is that between very different organisms, in this case between social amoebas and the bacteria that they both eat and house.

The investigators discovered that relatives are recognized by specific genetic markers in the social amoebas. They also found that these markers are not the only way that cooperation with relatives results. As the amoebas proliferate from a central place, they naturally sort into groups of relatives simply because the growing edge puts cells that have just divided, and so are identical, next to each other. The investigators also studied long distance dispersal of amoeba spores and found that flies can carry spores and they are more likely to do so if the spores are atop a stalk, as happens in the social stage of development.

Understanding the general principles that organize social interactions is an important area of investigation. One paper they wrote was on the veil of ignorance idea. This is the principle behind having the person who cuts the cake into pieces not get to choose the first piece. The cutting will be more fair if the decider does not know which piece she will get. In this social amoeba system, the veil of ignorance applies if an amoeba does not know if it will become dead stalk or living spore upon entering the social stage.

Amoeba carriage of bacteria turned out to be a very important topic for research. One of the places bacteria hide from antibiotics and other treatments is inside amoebas and in their spores. The investigators found that this was common in social amoebas. Some of the bacteria that the amoebas sequestered could later be used as food, but others could not. They discovered that the bacteria that could not be used as food could serve as weapons against other amoebas. They could also facilitate the carriage of bacteria that are good food. The non-food bacteria were beneficial to the amoeba strains from which they were isolated, but could prove very toxic to naïve amoeba hosts. The bacteria did not provide protection from nematode predators. This line of study also led the investigators to contribute to the general understanding of mutualistic interactions between kingdoms, in this case between amoebas and bacteria, but the theory can also be applied to interactions between other kingdoms, like insects and bacteria, or plants and insects.

One of the problems with any cooperative system whether it be within species or between, is freeloaders, or cheaters. The reason this can be a problem is captured in the simple statement that while it might be good to give assistance under many circumstances, it might be even better to receive that assistance. The investigators worked on this question and found that the kinds of structure that puts relatives together also selects against this kind of cheater, so they did not actually do better by acting selfishly, because that caused the whole system to break down.

Besides the advances that this research made in understanding interactions among amoebas and with bacteria, the investigators introduced to research many students at all levels from high school to undergraduate and graduate. Many of these students had their own research projects and learned how to ask and answer a scientific question using the scientific method and appropriate statistics. The investigators and their students shared information in various ways, including editing Wikipedia pages, teaching high school students in workshops, and in public poster sessions.

Infectious disease in humans is caused by relatives of the harmless bacteria and amoebas that the investigators study, so principles learned from this system can help the world understand how to control amoebas and bacteria and their interaction in ways of potentially vital importance to human health.
